trans-unit.source: Configuring Expressroute with NSPs
trans-unit.target: Configuring Expressroute with NSPs

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through setting up ExpressRoute through NSPs
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through setting up ExpressRoute through NSPs

trans-unit.source: Configure an ExpressRoute Connection through a Network Service Provider
trans-unit.target: Configure an ExpressRoute Connection through a Network Service Provider

trans-unit.source: To configure your ExpressRoute connection through a network service provider, you’ll need to complete multiple steps in the proper order.
trans-unit.target: To configure your ExpressRoute connection through a network service provider, you’ll need to complete multiple steps in the proper order.

trans-unit.source: These instructions will help you:
trans-unit.target: These instructions will help you:

trans-unit.source: Create and manage ExpressRoute circuits
trans-unit.target: Create and manage ExpressRoute circuits

trans-unit.source: Link a Virtual Network to the ExpressRoute circuit
trans-unit.target: Link a Virtual Network to the ExpressRoute circuit

trans-unit.source: Configuration Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Configuration Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you begin configuration, verify that you have met the following prerequisites:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin configuration, verify that you have met the following prerequisites:

trans-unit.source: Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Latest version of Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Latest version of Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: The following Virtual Network requirements:
trans-unit.target: The following Virtual Network requirements:

trans-unit.source: A set of IP address prefixes to be used in virtual networks in Azure.
trans-unit.target: A set of IP address prefixes to be used in virtual networks in Azure.

trans-unit.source: A set of IP prefixes on-premises (can contain public IP addresses).
trans-unit.target: A set of IP prefixes on-premises (can contain public IP addresses).

trans-unit.source: The Virtual Network Gateway must be created with a /28 subnet.
trans-unit.target: The Virtual Network Gateway must be created with a /28 subnet.

trans-unit.source: Additional set of IP prefixes (/28) that is outside of the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Additional set of IP prefixes (/28) that is outside of the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: This will be used for configuring routes.
trans-unit.target: This will be used for configuring routes.

trans-unit.source: – You will have to provide this to the network service provider.
trans-unit.target: – You will have to provide this to the network service provider.

trans-unit.source: AS number for your network.
trans-unit.target: AS number for your network.

trans-unit.source: You will have to provide this to the network service provider.
trans-unit.target: You will have to provide this to the network service provider.

trans-unit.source: You can use private AS numbers.
trans-unit.target: You can use private AS numbers.

trans-unit.source: If you choose to do so, it must be > 65000.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to do so, it must be > 65000.

trans-unit.source: For more information about AS numbers, see Autonomous System (AS) Numbers.
trans-unit.target: For more information about AS numbers, see Autonomous System (AS) Numbers.

trans-unit.source: From the network service provider:
trans-unit.target: From the network service provider:

trans-unit.source: You must have a VPN service that is supported with ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: You must have a VPN service that is supported with ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: Check with your network service provider if your existing VPN service qualifies.
trans-unit.target: Check with your network service provider if your existing VPN service qualifies.

trans-unit.source: Deployment Workflow
trans-unit.target: Deployment Workflow

trans-unit.source: Network Service Provider Workflow
trans-unit.target: Network Service Provider Workflow

trans-unit.source: Configuring Settings using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Configuring Settings using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell is a powerful scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of your workloads in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell is a powerful scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of your workloads in Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information please refer to the PowerShell documentation in [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj156055.aspx)
trans-unit.target: For more information please refer to the PowerShell documentation in [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj156055.aspx)

trans-unit.source: Import the PowerShell module for ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: Import the PowerShell module for ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: Get the list of providers, locations, and bandwidths supported.
trans-unit.target: Get the list of providers, locations, and bandwidths supported.

trans-unit.source: Before creating a circuit you will need a list of service providers, supported locations, and bandwidth options for each location.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a circuit you will need a list of service providers, supported locations, and bandwidth options for each location.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell cmdlet returns this information which you’ll use in later steps.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell cmdlet returns this information which you’ll use in later steps.

trans-unit.source: The information returned will look similar to the example below:
trans-unit.target: The information returned will look similar to the example below:

trans-unit.source: Make a request for a service key and pass it to your network service provider.
trans-unit.target: Make a request for a service key and pass it to your network service provider.

trans-unit.source: You will use a PowerShell cmdlet to make this request.
trans-unit.target: You will use a PowerShell cmdlet to make this request.

trans-unit.source: For this example we’ll use AT&T Netbond as the service provider and will specify a 50 Mbps ExpressRoute circuit in Silicon Valley.
trans-unit.target: For this example we’ll use AT&T Netbond as the service provider and will specify a 50 Mbps ExpressRoute circuit in Silicon Valley.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a different provider and different settings, substitute that information when making your request.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a different provider and different settings, substitute that information when making your request.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example request for a new service key:
trans-unit.target: Below is an example request for a new service key:

trans-unit.source: The response will be something similar to the example below:
trans-unit.target: The response will be something similar to the example below:

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve this information at any time using the Get-AzureCircuit cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve this information at any time using the Get-AzureCircuit cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Making the call without any parameters will list all circuits.
trans-unit.target: Making the call without any parameters will list all circuits.

trans-unit.source: Your Service Key will be listed in the ServiceKey field.
trans-unit.target: Your Service Key will be listed in the ServiceKey field.

trans-unit.source: Once this step is complete, you’ll have connectivity to Azure storage and other services.
trans-unit.target: Once this step is complete, you’ll have connectivity to Azure storage and other services.

trans-unit.source: Configure your Virtual Network and Gateway.
trans-unit.target: Configure your Virtual Network and Gateway.

trans-unit.source: See [Configure a Virtual Network and Gateway for ExpressRoute](../expressroute/expressroute-configuring-vnet-gateway.md).
trans-unit.target: See [Configure a Virtual Network and Gateway for ExpressRoute](../expressroute/expressroute-configuring-vnet-gateway.md).

trans-unit.source: Note that the gateway subnet must be /28 in order to work with an ExpressRoute connection.
trans-unit.target: Note that the gateway subnet must be /28 in order to work with an ExpressRoute connection.

trans-unit.source: Link your network to a circuit.
trans-unit.target: Link your network to a circuit.

trans-unit.source: Proceed with the following steps only after you have confirmed that your
trans-unit.target: Proceed with the following steps only after you have confirmed that your

trans-unit.source: ServiceProviderState: Provisioned
trans-unit.target: ServiceProviderState: Provisioned

trans-unit.source: Status: Enabled
trans-unit.target: Status: Enabled

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have at least one Azure virtual network with a gateway created.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have at least one Azure virtual network with a gateway created.

trans-unit.source: The gateway must be running.
trans-unit.target: The gateway must be running.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
